Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Blackberry yogurt with nut granola

qWS_Wt9XVB8C2NtH2U0vFQ.text: This was a complete accident finding this but wow!! What a great surprise! First of all the building is amazing! The artwork and the toon it self is like stepping back in time Not only is the coffee incredible, but the also offer great drinks to go with it! I had the boozy Abby manhatten with cold brew coffee brandy! Outstanding! They also have lunch and snacks there that looked amazing and a great outdoor seating area right In the heart of Larry-ville!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

OIi_1bAJcI3xi4TpyeCsig.text: Prior to starting our shopping adventure in Lville we stopped in for a coffee.  Having never been to the Abbey, we wondered around to look at the restaurant and bar and the interesting decor, too.  We enjoyed our coffee and off we went shopping.  Well next thing we know we were done shopping and had those hangry pains, so we stopped in at the bar for lunch.  Really enjoyed the atmosphere and good service.  The Cuban sandwich really hit the spot.  The Abbey was a nice place for a relaxing lunch.

aK1WcfbSJLq8c7ae4OOhfg.text: I will not be coming back unless it is for coffee and I have it on the patio. The hosts/hostesses aren't wearing uniforms and are unidentifiable in a crowd, especially when you are waiting for a table in another room and have no idea who to expect to call your name. The bussers didn't clean the coffee table in the coffee lounge until we asked them to do so. This was well before the Saturday night rush and dirty dishes were everywhere on the empty tables. The waitstaff seems very inexperienced and our waiter literally read the specials from his notebook like a robot. The menu is extremely limited and the food is extremely overpriced for the quality. Just putting Siracha on something doesn't increase its value or appeal. Two shrimp for $5? Mashed potatoes for $7?There are FAR superior places to eat in Lawrenceville. This place feels like Yinzers who are trying to be hip. Increase the menu options and train your waitstaff if you expect to maintain a competitive edge in this neighborhood.

pjCruTw4dLxxpQoIQv8MVg.text: I was really looking forward to this restaurant, as the building is beautiful and the patio is just so appealing.  Sadly, that is where my positives end.  I had noticed the previous night (online) that the menu is limited.  It doesn't really match up with the ambiance and style of the restaurant.  Mostly, it's just sandwiches with a salad option and a few appetizers.  Dinner wasn't that much better.  I did see several items, however, that I thought I would be happy with.  Like "Not your grandma's grilled cheese" and a red potato small plate.  The waiter told me these are not served at lunch, but I just looked online again now and they are listed as luncheon items.  Someone needs to correct their website.   The sandwiches didn't really appeal to me, other than maybe the hamburgers.  I'm not a picky eater, either, but there was always something that I didn't like about a particular sandwich (like curry which isn't my thing).  There were some appetizers and we ordered the zucchini with tempura batter.  It was cut in thick wedges and breaded and was pretty good - the only thing I really liked.  I ended up ordering the pulled pork hoagie with apricot BBQ sauce which sounded yummy.  After a discussion with the waiter, I was supposed to get my BBQ sauce on the side which didn't happen.  Instead it was soaked into the bread and I couldn't even really taste it.  The pork was dry and overly spiced.  I ate about three bites of it.  The sandwiches had a side of either pasta salad or fries (or an upgrade for a side salad).  We chose the pasta salad.  The pasta salad was a macaroni salad that was very similar to that you would get at a  bad deli.   They should not be listing that as a pasta salad.  It should be listed as macaroni salad.  One of our party got the grilled romaine with asiago cheese on top (she had been having some stomach issues and thought that would be the easiest on her stomach).  I thought it was an odd dish for an entree.  Maybe it would work as an appetizer salad.  That was it - the lettuce sprinkled with cheese.  The third party got the eggplant sandwich which she did like.  Our service was mediocre at best.  In addition to the BBQ sauce mistake, one of our party asked for an ice tea refill which she didn't get until she asked again.  I was never asked about a refill and the waiter was scarce.  They were not busy.   I also asked for something cool to put on my sandwich as it was so spicy.  The waiter said he would bring some ranch dressing which I didn't get until I asked him again.  By that time I knew I didn't like the sandwich and nothing would help it.  There were no desserts that we knew of, but he never really asked and we were going to walk to a nearby bakery where we felt we'd get better desserts anyway.  The place is beautiful and maybe good to sit at the bar.  They really need to re-do their menu.  It has nothing on it that would entice me to come back no matter what the atmosphere.  I do like gourmet food, but I think their menu is just odd, not gourmet or special.   There is a parking lot which is a plus in this busy area.

2Fm0hij2kLyfl-ZIKDArTg.text: Went here for dinner on a Saturday night.  Party of 2.  Arrived around 7:15 pm, we had reservations for 7:15 pm.  We were seated promptly, and the hostess was smiling and personable.  The side salads we ordered to have prior to our meal were fresh and the dressing was pleasant.  That's all I have to say that's positive about this place.  The service was slow (but oh wow, how quickly our server managed to pick up our check & take our money), our server never asked us how our food was, I had to ask 3 different people who brought food to our table or cleared plates for more water, the food was overpriced and I would deem it nothing better than "edible," the environment was far too loud to carry on a conversation, and the interesting lighting choices are overpowered by the huge television behind the bar.  My server asked if I wanted to wrap up half of the leftover hummus (I ordered it as a main dish because I wasn't particularly hungry) and I said "No thank you, it wasn't good," and the server replied: "Oh, that's too bad."  I feel like any sort of follow-up question might've saved me from deciding to never patronize this place again.  Like: "Oh, how was it not to your liking?" or even-- because again, I ate only half of it-- asking a manager to give us some sort of discount or coupon for future use or something, anything to demonstrate any sort of actual interest in the customer's experience.  Maybe we caught them on a bad night or at a bad time, I don't know.  If that's the case, as a customer, that's not my problem.  I've had very few dining experiences that were as bad as this one, and I don't ever want to go to The Abbey again.

mifomuVn_ljE_pqFIVtM9Q.text: Thought the place was too big to survive or make sense, and didn't like it when it first opened, this place has found it's place on Butler.  Good food, great patio.    Gets an older crowd generally...often the crowd that feels like drove in from Fox Chapel or something.  Locals seem to come out too.  Place has so many little rooms it's cool to see.

iDK9cYyu_rSSmQSJjxUfzA.text: Really good burgers  infact have not had a bad meal here . Great service . Will be back. Highly recommend if your visiting the Pittsburgh area!!!!

by5BE79u3ZEPNWCDR3iptg.text: Really liked the space. Menu a bit cumbersome. Food was abundant and good. Very Good drink selection. Service average but attentive. Definitely go back.

6TpzIikP3abesRrtTCYofg.text: Spent no less than 140 dollars as a table then after 2 people left we're forced to order food. We ordered food then still forced out of our patio seating. There are still 5- 2 tops open and 2- 4 tops available. Unsure why we were still forced out of seating, not to mention that it was rudely done with no apologies nor thank yous.

2koTWzEqSrbBusMmXNz6wA.text: There is a lot going on at the abbey and I was extremely pleased with my experience today. First off the outdoor patio is beautiful. Second, the dessert case inside was something different you and usually don't see that too many places.   My friend ordered edamame hummus with naan bread. It was sooo good! They gave you so much hummus and a lot of bread which is key. Some places give you so much dip and not enough bread, but the abbey delivered here. She also ordered the eggplant sandwich but she wasn't too wowed by it. She said it was pretty tasteless. I ordered the chicken and Gouda sandwich and it came with macaroni salad. I will say the macaroni noodles were on the hard side, but my sandwich was very juicy and flavorful! I would recommend this sandwich to everyone! Overall, my first experience at the abbey was a good one and I will return!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Patio
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken and Gouda Sandwich

nIS2KR3cufc3Awngs0s5cw.text: The fried zucchini app is the best! Such a cool atmosphere. The bar reminds me of s British pub. I'm really Glad to have this addition to the city. Great cocktails and the steak was excellent.

NkpjKT1D3yjYa_um_d66OQ.text: I like sitting at the bar, so that is exactly what I did. Bartenders were attentive. Beer selection is pretty good - tends to gravitate more toward IPAs and ales but something for everyone.   Prices for beer are average (compared to other places) and for food, prices also range from average to a little pricier. I had the provolone burger (good) with the house pasta salad (a little too al dente).   What made this experience for me was the music. Funk soul Motown on a Sunday night. I don't know if that's the usual since it was my first time going but ... Perfect.

0hG8qVpQIc1uyf_gNKXTdg.text: I love how beautiful this place is and a great location. Cocktails are clever. But, the coffee is bland and we've actually stopped going here because the food is so boring and the service awful. They weren't even busy the last couple of times we were there, but our servers would just disappear. For the price, I'd rather have delicious food and coffee and pleasant service.

ekljfnvezHrOBVAX8jIadQ.text: The Abbey is un-arguably part of the wave of kind-of-expensive restaurants flooding Butler Street in the past couple of years, but it's one of few that really makes up for its price and crowd with amazing service and hugely-portioned, quality food.   I'm not sure if they intend to have a British-inspired pub menu from now on, or if it rotates, but if you go while they have fish and chips or bangers and mash, I've loved both the handful of times I've been here, and had leftovers of both (which held up well the next day, even!).  The place itself is gorgeous and was the perfect place to bring my out-of-town parents and in-laws for dinner and drinks. They take reservations and have a ton of space, indoor and out.

ypVREOg_aw_nGpMAgJAoMQ.text: I was skeptical after reading mixed reviews but we had a great experience! The food was phenomenal-- the scallops are amazing, and the chicken and lamb sausage entrees were also really good, though the drinks were by far the highlight of the meal. The service was great at first but became very slow as the dinner crowd started coming in, but we weren't in a rush and didn't mind too much. Overall, The Abbey definitely exceeded my expectations!

I1bcCo7Z53soYGW2M5qkVg.text: Tried this place for the first time last night. My wife has been here before and had the scallops, they were wonderful. Last night we both had the burger. Nothing to write home about. At 15 bucks a piece including  cheese and some extras, not worth it.  I had two beers she had two wines and the bill came to 60 plus dollars.  The other food patrons were eating looked fabulous We will definitely come back to try other food. There was great outdoor seating and we were seated immediately. Overall, I would not get the burgers here again but will try other food. Three stars for the burgers.

ny6btm_UbmEUp-QnyOAKOA.text: The ambiance, outdoor and indoor seating, and nice mix of bar/coffee/restaurant gets a 4 out of 5 stars.  It's also great that there is some parking available (probably mostly free earlier in the day).  In Lawrenceville, fast/easy parking is a plus.  I'd give the food a 2 out of 5.  The ~$12 sandwiches should be priced at $8 and are still mediocre.  We've had lunch here 2x and I think it's the last.

eoQ69CWZIpnpv2nSfkswEg.text: I tried the Abbey for drinks with a friend last night, and overall it was a really positive experience. I walked in and the friendly host let me know that the bar area was self-seating and that we could order at the bar if we chose one of the nearby high top tables. I decided on that, and the ordering process was smooth overall. I was always able to quickly get the bartender's attention for drink refills, and when I ordered some fries someone brought them right to the table. If you opt to be seated in the dining room, that comes with full table service.   The bar area itself got a bit noisy due to some rather raucous middle-aged patrons (I pray for that much energy once I'm their age!) so in the future I'll probably seek out the couches in the quieter lounge space on the other side of the wall. That was my only quibble however, and with how large the building appears to be I'm sure there are plenty of places to camp out with drinks and relax. I can't extensively comment on the food, but I may increase this to a 5-star review if it turns out to taste as great as it looked and smelled. One final note: The draft list was wonderful! There were lots of excellent choices and flights were only $8, which will keep me coming back for sure.

S1ViRGjqj3f8rP73M5bf-w.text: A great restaurant that has a coffeehouse embedded into it. Lounged with a cold brew for a while, then decided to be seated out on their patio for some food. Salad special was delicious and I just relaxed for a while and read.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

2vnjj90NWedMGjj2QrZ63g.text: What to do with a place like The Abbey? Is it a restaurant or a coffee house? It's both, and they do each, incredibly.   Drinks, they have one of the best Old Fashioneds in the Burgh. A little sweet, great bourbon flavor comes through with a little of the citrus peel to enhance it.   Dinner, opted for a burger, and ordered the house made vegetarian patty with smoked cherry tomatoes, garlic aioli, frisee and Asiago. It's really one of the best House made, meatless patties I've ever had. Perfect bun and a side pasta salad. Excellent!   Coffee/dessert. We got up from the bar and went to the coffee house and enjoyed a raspberry thumbprint and Latte. We sat out on the patio and enjoyed the nice evening. A beautiful fountain in the center is very relaxing and makes for a focal point for diners. The thumbprint was vegan and raw, made with dates, cashews and a dab of (house made?) raspberry preserves, friend of Joe had a  Blondie, she said was chewy, caramelly and rich.   I must put The Abbey on my regular rotation, perhaps stop some Sunday for Brunch. Kitchen closes at 10pm. Two parking lots, if they're filled there's street parking.

hJJ5pciMkBGHlk1hNeJQTQ.text: Great brunch and service. The outside area is really pretty with a lot of shading. Everything came out quick, and awesome ambiance.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Veggie omelette.

LzxHHmDbEE6TVuXPCP-g-A.text: I hosted a going away happy hour at the Abbey last Thurs. for a group of my friends.  I chose the Abbey as the location because it encompasses a bar, a restaurant, and a coffee bar, and therefore is capable of satisfying a variety of tastes.  Additionally, it is quite large and has a lot of seating, including a pleasant-looking outdoor seating area, so I figured it could easily accommodate my group regardless of how many people ended up showing up.  Because the Abbey doesn't accept reservations, I arrived at the beginning of my event with a couple of guests and explained the situation to them.  The hostess told me that they normally wait for the entire group to show, but because my guests would be filing in and out over the course of two hours, she had us hang out at the bar while she prepared a table for us.  The table that we ended up at was between the bar and the foyer, and we didn't have consistent waitservice during our visit, but it did allow guests to come and go easily, which was nice.  For my drink, I ordered a prosecco, which was $1 off for happy hour ($7).  It was exactly what i expected--nothing too out of the ordinary, just a basic dry wine-like alcoholic beverage.  As a snack, I ordered the Yukon gold smashed potatoes ($7), which were miniature potato cakes topped with cheese and a garnish of aromatic green herbs.  They were rather bland to the point that I requested salt and pepper to impart some flavor to them.  Like the beverage, they weren't bad, but were nothing too special.  My other guests ordered a variety of drinks and food, including beer, cider, and cocktails as well as burgers and other small plates.  I can't comment on them because I didn't try them, but my guests didn't complain but didn't rave, either.  Based on my experience, I'd say that the Abbey is an A-OK spot to host a happy hour or other informal gathering.  The service was sporadic and the food was okay, but the setting was nice and offered something for everyone.  At the time of our visit, we were unable to take advantage of the outdoor seating because of rainy weather, but it looked like it'd be nice if weather permits.  The Abbey offers a welcome alternative to the many loud bars on Butler St. such as Industry, so be sure to check it out with your group.  3.5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Arsenal cider, prosecco, and smashed Yukon gold potatoes

hckpEFuSbc6eJHiWfKsO3A.text: Ugh ignorant nasty and rude service ... our waiter knew not one thing he claimed and never decided to maybe go ask someone more knowledgeable ... our food was fair at best and not totally correct ... we asked if we could purchase coffee beans - of course he said i don't kno ?!? We asked if he could find out ... he told us maybe Thursday and it could be purchased but to just go somewhere else for coffee beans as did the girl at the coffee bar ... ?!? Saying "u can go get that commonplace  coffee anywhere" ... that's crazy ... because if we come back for coffee beans - then most likely we'll have a cup there also and lunch/dinner a few overpriced weak cocktails followed by maybe more coffee and dessert ... like if u give a mouse a cookie  bad bad business ... beautiful space but the overall experience was awful due to the pretentious ignorant nasty servers

sQUZhH9KwXvWs3t8ZTt0ow.text: Love. Love. Love. Today i decided to meet a friend of mine at The Abbey. I had been once before, but it was a few years ago only for drinks. Today, i had lunch and it was fantastic. I asked for seating in the outdoor patio area,the hostess was very pleasant and accommodating. What a wonderful place to have lunch outside in the city. So tranquil, and welcoming, perfect summer lunch spot. Our server, David, was delightful. He was very knowledgeable and friendly. The food was delicious! my friend and i both ordered the salad w/grilled chicken. House dressing was amazing. I will most certainly be returning soon, can't believe it took me this long to go back!

6ebyEkiTNGr7PjS5x-NE_w.text: I highly recommend the Abbey for brunch on Sundays! At the beginning of the meal they serve the table banana bread, which is amazing! I enjoyed the vegan pancakes for my meal and they tasted great! You can hardly tell them apart from regular pancakes. The rest of my party ordered omelettes, which were also very cheesey and delicious! I particularly love this restaurant because of the atmosphere. The Abbey has so much history and is set up to look like an old English pub.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

6FKrw1Z9_2FiEfpdOxlMIg.text: The only good thing to say is that had the wings and they were very good. We sat at the bar and the service was extremely poor. We sat there without being approached for a few minutes while there was only one other person (an employee) sitting at the bar also. There were 3 women behind the bar but one seemed to be only pouring table drinks, another complained to the other about work, and talked to the employee sitting at the bar. After our wings came we were never approached again until we place the empty dish at top of bar. We waited with empty drinks for over 5 minutes before being asked if we needed anything. We got our check and left. Again, it was very slow there except for 3-4 employees standing around complains about their jobs.

z9NcKhIwOy3Syg6iHWYrYQ.text: Good for: Happy hour, at the bar, with a small group of people, assuming it's not very busy.  Also good for: A quick coffee if you're not very picky, maybe a small bite from their coffee bar.  Bad for: Dinner, dates, group outings, brunches, sitting outside without paying exorbitant premiums or minimum purchase requirements.  Expect to pay too much money for food that is just OK and service that will probably leave you frustrated. There are better places to eat and drink in the area.

FFmWkpiDMNcNuKclNp3JlQ.text: Ive been here a handful of times for a cocktail, during the cookie walk we tested the Bloody Mary and liked them ...... so this time when we ordered the house (premixed) was way too heavy on the horseradish in my opinion.  I could not taste anything but the horseradish, the color of the juice was even not red because of it.  They had no fancy garnish, not even olives or celery when I asked (?).  I guess they must have changed their house recipe from before and cut down on on the garnish, although I don't remember the price being cut back :(.  We sat at the bar, the building is amazing and beautiful to enjoy.  The bartender was not very attentive.

zJ61pbPa2iOhqEWVW9PdzA.text: My wife,daughter and her friend dined here Saturday evening and had a horrible experience with manager "Tim"... he was rude to my daughter and her friend and actually cursed at them twice (I.e. "mf'er"...and "get the f out of here". Nice way to handle paying, female customers...."Tim" doesn't even deserve to be cleaning floors at a McDonald's let alone being the face of a restaurant....ownership take heed....but they said the food was good. But you can bet no one in our family will ever go

u2ylrCKhkVg2cAzt3Ctv0g.text: Music selection on point! Lovely place to study for a few hours and then switch it up to beer  overall nice ambiance. Bar deals/happy hour could be better.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

IMnbQqeVW1Dk5zls3MdycQ.text: I'm in Pittsburgh visiting friends and they recommended this place for dinner. The atmosphere is 5 stars. It's unique and beautiful, as well as huge!  It's a little on the pricier side but nothing crazy. The food was absolutely incredible. I got the abbeys Mac and cheese and it was honestly the best Mac and cheese I've ever had. It has pepperoni in it, which I didn't eat, but my husband said it was good if you like that kind of thing. My husband got the bourbon peanut butter and jelly burger, and said it was ok.. nothing special but he liked it. Our friend got the chicken dinner and I had a couple of bites and it was amazing.   Our server was friendly and patient and I really liked him. The craft beers were in the $5 range which is very affordable, but my wine was $8 a glass with a very small pour. I should have gotten the bottle. Oh well.   The only reason this place does not have 5 stars is the way the host treated us. There were three of us and we wanted to sit on the patio. She said well we only allow guests to eat on the patio who are doing dinner. Ok b..... we are going to eat dinner. Who said we weren't? She really tried to push us to eat anywhere else, on a Monday, when they were dead. It was really insulting and she was ignorant. It got better though.

aEpVB7q6nzGsQSh3wbd6tQ.text: If it weren't for the food and the outdoor seating, I wouldn't come here. The staff at best ignore you and at worst (which is more frequent) treat you like you're a nuisance.    I'm the type to withhold criticism favoring to give situations the benefit of the doubt, but when you've  been to an establishment 6-7 times (mostly during non busy hours) & have staff look you in the eye and just keep walking; staff silently move past you and nearly bump into you without so much as a acknowledgement of your presence; bartenders/wait staff neglecting to take your order or give you the check until you flag them down plus the condescending attitude of host/hostesses, it's official:  The Abbey does not make you feel welcomed.

wrTO9D1RvZarSYa2Iwq3fQ.text: Weird place and weird menu.... Had the fish and chips and the Abbey Hash.  Abbey Hash was on the menu for $10.00 but when the bill came, we were charged $12.00. The Fish & Chips was large but had a lot of breading. Service was ok.... Kinda of a "meh".... Won't go back here.

HJppnHw9d1g8WIdEUJLukw.text: When I'm in the mood for a truly unique atmosphere with great drinks and killer apps, my mind goes instantly to The Abbey. You open the giant front door to a chic interior of beautiful woodwork, wooden ceilings, and exposed brick. It has a warm and welcoming ambiance coupled with a killer staff - you won't want to leave! We sat at the bar and ordered their prosecco - on tap! It's really great quality; I even dared to have a second glass! We also ordered the Pub Curry Fries, which are a large serving of meaty fries doused in a deliciously amazing curry and cheese sauce, then topped with melted cheese, all served in a hot cast-iron tray. It's honestly hard to stop eating them, and we were headed elsewhere for dinner!  I don't live in Pittsburgh anymore, so when I come to The Abbey it's always a real treat. I wholeheartedly recommend this amazing bar and restaurant!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

giuk2xCiHJJzJa_Zbu9Wcg.text: I went for Sunday brunch- and although I was expecting the buffet style breakfast I had read about online, they didn't have a buffet. We ordered off the menu instead and it was delicious. More than enough food! (so we didn't even need a buffet) The waiter offered us coffee cocktails and menu suggestions and was helpful and pleasant. My favorite part of the experience was the atmosphere inside. The friend I took even said "We walked in here and it feels like a vacation." We were not rushed, it was pleasant and comfortable. I would definitely recommend.

RkQj-_Aho4clAqS1hFR1Gw.text: Stopped here for dinner with my boyfriend because the reviews were good and we needed to have dinner after a long day of travel.   The decor is dark and "pub" like and quite large. We got a cute little table on the patio where we ordered drinks and dinner. The service was fast and friendly, the drinks were OK, and the food was decent.    Something that was kind of strange was the music choice. They were playing popular hits but it didn't seem to match the look and feel of the resturant, it was kind of disrupting the mood. I think they could really benefit from playing more dinner appropriate music during dinner.

CKLuSjyTm2XaRoSgQKy9zA.text: The Abby has one of the coolest venues in Lawrenceville. In one restaurant, there's a coffee shop, a bar, and a warm little restaurant. I loved the atmosphere, and I could come here for dinner, to do some reading, or to hang out with friends, making it very dynamic. I was also really impressed with the food for the most part. They have some really cool coffee based drinks that were excellent. In addition, I enjoyed the lamb fries a lot (and they didn't skimp on the meat). the only thing I wasn't ecstatic with was the mahi mahi (I think? It was a fish fillet) with saffron risotto. The saffron didn't really come through for me and the fish was a little bland. It wasn't terrible, but I wouldn't order it again. I can't wait to come back and try something new!

G4o15Ili_TWa51PqzPeStQ.text: Very cute concept. There's a bar, coffee shop and a restaurant all in one place.  This restaurant is on one of the hippest, most progressive streets in Pittsburgh and they offer zero vegan options.  Even the seitan option had parmesan cheese on it? All the breads had dairy in them.  Very confused and a bit shocked by all that.  Other than that, if you're not vegan, there are many options on the menu for you.

9tDjtMER_8V1BUqLiBayPw.text: I had my first experience at The Abbey for brunch this past Sunday. After having a very difficult and disappointing reservation experience we went in with low expectations. The manager on duty over the phone "Nick" was extremely rude and act as if we were doing them a favor to dine at their establishment. After being told we could not add one more to our reservation we were hesitant to still go. When arriving we soon found out we could of added multiple people to the reservation and it would not have been an issue. The manager on duty that day apologized and did buy the first round of drinks; which was appreciated. However, the food was OK, nothing to write home about and it was incredibly hot in the room they set us up in. A very disappointing experience and won't be back again. Way too many options around the city with way better customer service.

lu6HwvPsOFOEldX2wnOCDg.text: One of the more decent bars/pubs on Butler street which I tend to find overly expensive and overrated. The food was good and my portion was huge! Drinks were also pretty good with a huge even overwhelming cocktail list. Not super cheap, but in line with other Lawrenceville places and the nice ambiance made it more worth it.

v7j0MU2l9no9ddtDfsLG_A.text: I had pretty high expectations of this restaurant,  from what friends had told me, but I was somewhat let down by it. The appetizers we ordered were great. We got the lamb fries, bruschetta plate, and stuffed pretzel. The plates were large and enough to share with our group of 11. The lamb fries were my favorite of the appetizers. The fries were still crispy even though they were covered in lamb meat and cheese. The dish also had a good flavor combination. Where I was disappointed in my visit here was my entree. I ordered the Abbey Burger and it was very over cooked. It was practically burnt, to the point that I couldn't taste the bacon, garlic aoli, or tomato. I ordered it medium, so I was disappointed I couldn't taste anything but the burnt flavor. The pasta salad that came on the side was very good though. Covered in plenty of cheese and sauce. It was fresh and refreshing from my heavy and overdone burger.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Abbey Burger
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lamb Fries

SK__tHCnBe3AIyBHXQ1uUQ.text: This is one of my favorite places in the city. The inside is a retro speak easy type of vibe since it use to be a funeral home. They have a coffee bar and sitting area, a pub style bar, restaurant sitting area and an outdoor sitting area with a fountain. The food is excellent and the coffee is really good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cheese fries with curry sauce
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Atlantic salmon char with potatoes
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

AbyAJ0b-kCGM6Mc1HZVgkQ.text: This it's the worst meal I've ever had I don't think the chef understands how to make food that doesn't have too much salt in it I had the vegetarian ravioli it was in edible we also had the veggie burger it was deep fried and greasy do not go here the food is not good.

ft5LjBcjlQfMEt4H_7xVTg.text: The Abbey is a pretty interesting space at the end of one of the more lively streets in Pittsburgh. Although we didn't sit there, the outdoor seating looked cozy and there was a front room (front left) that had a nice vibe. So that's the good part.   Beer selection was tolerable but not fantastic.   The food was pretty OK, just pretty OK. Bar food, nothing ventured, nothing lost. Slightly overcooked here and there, but nothing you wouldn't expect.    Service likewise was tolerable - a bit of faux pleasantness and slight inattentiveness, but  given the sparse turnout in the bar area (where we ate), not surprising I guess.   What was surprising was the strange management person and her arbitrary rules about which tables were reserved. APPARENTLY, the entire back bar area is reserved, except for literally at the bar. The front bar, well, NOT like that, anything goes there. We were literally and unceremoniously ejected from the back bar area, despite the helpful hostess telling us it was OK. Someone had a bad day/week/life.  Would I go back? Definitely for a drink, dining atmosphere, even in the forbidden back bar, leaves a lot to be desired. So does the customer service.

-kwXDS9QnQhr1IRAP6X0jw.text: Went with friends, ordered the Edamame hummus with naan and veggies-very yummy! It kinda ended after that. I ordered a burger, it was dry and flavorless even though I paid $3 extra for the coffee rub. My friend ordered the veggie burger and the flavor was good, however it wasn't a burger, more like quinoa on a hamburger bun. I felt like it was very over priced for the quality of food. Will rethink happy hour next time!

LHTYHkY5HakX9hHx0ZqJ0A.text: Went here for brunch which is served buffet style. We sat on the patio with our friends and the baby and the service was great. Bottles of water on the table to help keep us hydrated.   I had a greenflash passion power beer which was delicious and refreshing with breakfast. There were also different breakfast cocktail options and our friends each had one including a boozy iced coffee and a bellini. My husband had a pineapple cider(least favorite of the bunch). Coffee was also included on the buffet.   The food was good. It was a small selection of well done food! The fruit was fresh, the biscuits and veggie sausage gravy was delicious and you would never know that the gravy was vegetarian. My favorite item on the buffet was the breakfast sausage. There was also an omelet station which our friends really liked.   I can't wait to go back to try some coffee from their cafe and more of their menu!

aRzceYfR3CRevl5Vc0UVPg.text: I've been here to work alone and in groups, for coffee, beer and for dinner.  It's all great.  There are plants of places to sit and read/work and there's free wifi and plenty of coffee and tea and snacks.  When the day wears on, you can switch to beer.  The bar side gets a little rowdy in the evening but it's a fun place.  Dinner is a bit pricey in the restaurant but it's tasty.

ZB9ca2yMQ7OCJ4Z_ilU59A.text: The Abbey is a spot that literally has it all - coffee, beer, food.  I've been here for all three, and have been pleased each time. While at first I was skeptic that a place could succeed while wearing so many hats, they seem to have found a nice balance. Today my husband and I went for the coffee branch of the restaurant, and were quite please. We shared a brownie, I got a coffee cocktail, and he had a spiked apple cider. All three were delicious, and now he can't wait to come back for dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Pv9d_5MNHRufmxxbJ_LgJQ.text: Fantastic! Friends & family were in town from LA last night. After meeting at Grapperia we could not decide where to head for food that would be substantial.   Lawrenceville has a lot of places to eat. It starts to feel like every place in the neighborhood feels the same & serve the same type of meal. After much debating, a friend suggested we retry this location. Boy, were they correct that this was the place to go!  We started our group with a table order of curry fries, zucchini, chicken dip, & hummus. I can't tell you how the hummus was because they use Edamame in the hummus which I have an allergy towards.  Which is disappointing for me. However, other seemed to like it but nowhere near as much as the Sriracha chicken dip. Which had just the perfect amount of heat and savory chicken when paired with the pita. Of course our group had to order a second order of the Chicken dip w pita.  It was DELICIOUS.  We enjoyed the zucchini served with aioli with its fat, freshly breaded spears however the Curry Cheese Fries were borderline addictive in comparison. I didn't anticipate the fries to be as amazing as they were. To me they just don't sound amazing when ordering. When presented. Oh. My. Gawd. Are they delicious!!!  The French fries are seasoned ever so slightly with a curry. Not to heavily but just enough to pair perfectly with the Welsh Cheddar they're smothered on top.  Like I mentioned, I didn't expect to like this but I couldn't believe I LOVED these fries.   I love where The Abbey is headed. The bar of course was slammed while we were there. Strangely the restaurant area was quieter than I expected.  One thing I find disappointing about The Abbey is that as a restaurant smack dab within a multigenerational neighborhood, they make no provisions to accommodate families in their cafe or dining room. The lack of a high chair speaks volumes about the type of neighbor they plan to be. And that's a bit disappointing. Especially for a multi space venue like the Abbey that serve as a coffee shop & restaurant; and not just another bar.

KsVa5xKA7nIOCMQJiByIqQ.text: The Abbey is awesome. It just opened and I feel that it's going to do very well. The building is an old funeral home that they converted into a bar/restaurant/coffee shop and the space is massive. Renovations turned out beautifully and have created a warm, tasteful and comfortable ambiance, you definitely wouldn't know it was once a funeral home. There are at least two separate bars that I found, which helps bring the spaces together. Super happy to live so close and looking forward to coming here often.  I haven't had a chance to eat at The Abbey, but my friends say the food is delicious, and the coffee, too. My experience was at the bar where they had knowledgeable and friendly staff, a very wide selection of craft beers (most of them local, even better) and a pleasant/fun/yuppie crowd. We grabbed our drinks and wandered around, taking it all in. The lounge with the fireplace is perfect for chatting, and I can't wait to spend the summer in their gorgeous courtyard.

Qwc6qfNgzrgNIBqJ_6mLNw.text: Food wasn't what I expected. Really heavy, and extremely overcooked. Service wasn't all that great either. This was a one and done

F0JanyHsrsz7GQnCozgfQA.text: This is the BEST burger I've had in Pittsburgh so far. Can't say it enough. Go here and get the smoked provolone burger with bacon. It's amazing. It's on the same par as Butterjoint, which is a burger haven as well.  I honestly don't know why BRGR or Burgatory keeps coming up as a place to go for a burger, when really, they can't compare to this place in quality

VTxQrXcZWoIglLOs2UTAYA.text: Creepy confusing renovated funeral home ... The bartender was eating pizza behind the bar. Not one person approached us we just walked around aimlessly trying to figure out where to go or how to order. Also, they have the flower delivery sign still up from when it was a funeral home. The vibe was sad and depressing and it just felt creepy. Saturday brunch on May 14th.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Creepy funeral sign for flower delivery

h4VUfUm1sK0-FWmJ-B7woQ.text: Went today for brunch and had a good meal with nice service. Their French 75 was one of the best I've had, with lots of fresh lemon. I ordered the corned beef hash which was tasty and filling. The people I was with had been there once before for brunch and ordered the Montecristo for a 2nd time. They were a bit disappointed comparing the sandwich.

Wu5R1fsnDcqM2ldp8shMYQ.text: One of the best patio in city for sure. But i cant say same thing for food quality. We had dinner I ordered shepperd which was okay. And then I went to bar section after my dinner. It was exactly 9:55 and that guy told me he closed espresso when i asked latte. And he was weird. He is like we close at 10 im like its not 10 yet. Not cool

vl6FBei8GfP37leR5MQJ5A.text: Came here for a Tuesday dinner, awesome atmosphere and they make my favorite drink!  I got the backyard burger and it was very tasty.   Would definitely recommend a visit!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sitting in one of the nooks off the bar.

aOTJhfmwFWM_NFRLWXjZ2w.text: The team behind the Abbey has done an amazing job renovating this old funeral home into a beautiful restaurant full of intimate nooks where you and your friends can gather for a beer, coffee, or dinner. They also have the best patio in Lawrenceville, perfect for summer nights.   While the bar has a broad selections of beers and cocktails the food menu is strange and lacking in options. The menu is weighted heavy towards appetizers and small plates while leaving your entre selections limited to 2 burgers or 3 heavy/creamy pastas. I couldn't tell if they are going for a tapas style situation here or what the reason is for such a limited menu. I'd love to see another sandwich option or two and something like a chicken/pork chop/fish entre, especially during the summer months...I'm not looking for buttery pasta when its 80+ outside.   I'll definitely be back and hopefully they expand the menu and take advantage of this beautiful space.

KwrCxxWb1gaG0pJhpc-ywA.text: We went here for a weekend lunch. It wasn't too busy, but a little dim inside. The interior is different than a lot of restaurants in the area and I loved it! Do yourself a favor and get the Edamame Hummus to start! It's by far the best hummus I've ever had! I had the grilled eggplant sarnie with the pasta salad and it did not disappoint. This is a cool spot that I'm glad we tried! I'll definitely be back.

9bsw_JH3YGjmzJYwd-iGyg.text: Kitchen closed from 3:15 to 4:00. Uncommon, but we were prepared to be flexible. Offered us seats to wait in the sun. We asked for low tables in the shade to wait. We were refused even though other patrons were seated finishing their meal. We were told by the manager that people would be confused if we were allowed to sit there.  They were not accommodating and were patronizing. I will never go back.

Fz4_FSbIfVQ4kTUyPtGc_w.text: The Abbey is such an interesting concept with a young edgy vibe, the coffee shop has some of the best coffee I've ever tasted and the food is to die for, I would definitely recommend enjoying one of their amazing coffees outside in the sunshine by the beautiful fountain :)  Can't wait to come back

e1gSASqxxu7XqCe6rdw40g.text: We went here for the weekend brunch. Avoid it at all costs. I'm not sure if it was because it was New Years Day or what but the food was really rough. There are far better places in Lawrenceville to spend $40 for brunch. The biscuits were hard as rocks and the rest of the food was very cold.

NoggsEQwhOufN1KnCLd-ww.text: While our first visit sans child was nice enough, upon our return with our 1 year we were told they don't have high chairs or booster seats making it clear parents aren't welcome. Way to alienate a rich demographic who loves brunch! We had hoped to enjoy the arts fest and flea market as well. I guess "breeders" aren't allowed to have lives and go to cool events. Not only will we not return we'll spread the word among all our parent friends.

UNok7wVAsOHpF43cqtr_-A.text: I didn't realize this place was not kid friendly- my bad. But when the hostess asked me to take my baby out and around the building in the rain Because a private party was in the hallway and she didn't want me to push him through-I was taken aback. The gentlemen graciously stepped aside for me, thankfully. But that was completely ridiculous. Food was ok- nothing to write home about. The atmosphere was decent, given it was an old funeral home.

Hk0ruvU9NuItFSxij-c-Fg.text: Love the brunch menu. Has lots of Great  selection of alcohol. Have friends who don't eat meat? Well they can find a few unique dishes here. So it's good for the whole gang .

Cd2YH86fq9SeeAK9xMvlmg.text: We were very disappointed by the arbitrary rules about where you can sit. We were told that we couldn't sit outside because only one member of our party was eating food despite the entire outside being empty at 7pm on a Tuesday. Our friend who wanted food in the same establishment was told he couldn't order it because we were forced to sit inside. If you're trying to have an enjoyable experience, don't come here.

hbctNwGGD7MLD5fa64qw_Q.text: Stopped in for drinks on a Wednesday evening while visiting a friend in the city. The patio and decor of the restaurant were nice and inviting, and a lot of people of all different ages seemed to be going in. However, I think our decision to sit at/in the bar area rather than the patio was where we went wrong.  We sat at a hightop table in the bar area, and were eventually given menus. We were somewhat sternly instructed that if/when we wanted anything we had to request and pick up from the bar. We understood this may just have been policy, and ultimately both the bartender and barback would come out fairly often from behind the bar to ask if we needed anything. Service was just a bit inconsistent, but our drinks were fine.

WrS5od3bYzAtr-dO4FpGjQ.text: To say they're not kid friendly is an understatement. The hostess was downright rude when she smugly told us there were no high chairs or booster seats. If they don't want kids that badly, make it more explicit on the website to prevent people from feeling so unwelcome. Our waiter was nice, food was okay but not amazing, and the bloody Mary's were too spicy and undrinkable. Won't be returning.

wIXiC0c27bEfZk8PAS0Cig.text: We decided to try a new place every weekend instead of going to our comfortable regulars. This place will become a comfortable regular!  Hostesses we're so friendly; server was quiet but helpful; beer options were awesome; food was spectacular. We started with the Sriracha chicken dip with naan. GET IT!  Then we had the mac and cheese with chicken and Sheppard's pie. Both entrees were beyond expectation and the mac and cheese provided a great leftover lunch!   Combine all this with a really cool atmosphere and it makes a new favorite spot for us!

2EBHgsDUkobv8o4iDINCFQ.text: Nice enough space, especially when the patio is open. Bar selection is adequate, service is unremarkable, food is shockingly bad. If you go here, eat literally anywhere else in Lawrenceville first.

mS07HnS5rVNl1r2Y4WjqFQ.text: I'm not sure I wanted to even give it one star. Didn't have a good selection of scotch! The bartender wanted to debate American oak scotch (much different profile than sherry or port cask aging). Not one spyelside in sight! Then they  crammed a large group in a booth for four.    The appetizer the chicken dip tasted like canned devilwood chicken with sirachia sauce. Very, very limited menu, I had burger my wife had Mac and cheese. Both horrible! Burgers I have had a red robin were 1000% better than the frozen over cooked thing that I had. The Mac and cheese was well not good at all. After we left we stopped for something to eat.   If you want a good burger go to Tessaro's!  Also $14 for a 2 oz wine!  Noise level beyond the roar of a jet engine!

UT_5vm5y7VcRqEg8oOkndQ.text: Been to the Abbey twice now and had a great time. Wait staff was very friendly and knowledgeable, keeping the meals moving along but not bugging you too much.  The drink list is above average. Nice selection of drafts and a thoughtful selection of cocktails that were very enticing. Both summer and fall had a nice unique mixture of seasonal cocktails as well.  The food is uniformly excellent. Fun and flavorful. The chicken sirrachi dip starter and crab cakes were standout dishes.

1MW9nIdw1Mx8GmxUAsx6gw.text: Been here twice now. I LOVE the backyard burger. Seriously one of the best burgers I have ever eaten in my life. The first time I went here was during the week and we had no problem getting a table. The second time I went was yesterday (Friday night). Apparently you need reservations on the weekend. No problem though, there were plenty of tables in the bar area for us to enjoy dinner. We still received great service in the bar area, staff was friendly and my food was so good. Another bonus about this place is they have 2 parking lots. A rare thing to find in Lawrenceville. I will definitely be back!

8vqSxwciXlv-lSUUGbqsKA.text: Dude your hostess sucks, please retrain to learn how to handle customers. Who makes people wait 15 min to get seated when your entire restaurant is empty??

Yb-PDh2JH2c8xCRg5ngZug.text: TL; DR - Atmosphere is wonderful. Coffee and drinks are great. Food is meh, with some serious misses, service is horrendous.   Details - I am not a particularly picky person, but the service at the Abbey was apalling. The person who greeted us was rude. After a wait, and a weird attitude, we asked if they served food here or just drinks. She then asked us "Are you here for lunch or brunch?", it was our first time there and it was about 1 pm so we said "Lunch". To which she replied, "Sorry we only serve brunch on the weekend". Why the attitude and the question then!   Other issues with service, the wait staff was kind of bad at their job. The plates smelled of old food and the dishes still had food stuck on them even though they had clearly been in the dishwasher, and no one gave us any instructions regarding the buffet (e.g. Where is the buffet table? Do we leave our plates when going for a second round or use the same plates?). Pet peeve which bothered me but might not bother other people: wait staff would respond to questions with "Huh?" instead of "I didn't catch that" or "Could you repeat that?" or just a simple, "Sorry?". Also if we had a question or wanted someone to get us the check and they needed to consult another staff person or something, they would yell at each other from across the room, instead of just going and talking to one another.  They were out of much of the food, a lot of it didn't taste good at all although the french toast was it's redeeming quality.   The coffee? Amazing. Some of the best coffee we have had in Pittsburgh. Also a really good hot chocolate. The vibe was really great and fun and the decor is phenomenal.   Bring people to the coffee bar. You will get the good vibes, the service is much better and the drinks are worth it. I, however, am never bringing anyone to the actual restaurant.

HHtmRsMMs-udWJx0Uk4H1w.text: Worst smelling men's bathroom in Pittsburgh. get that fixed and I'll change this review because its fun but this bathroom smells worst than a locker room.

UxX5kMXQtTED0Z2s3yLraA.text: I've been to The Abbey quite a few times now (10+?) so there are obviously things to like about it: the location is great, parking is usually pretty easy, the space is beautiful, and with so few outdoor spaces in Pittsburgh the patio is fantastic.   But the service is the thing that's going to keep me from going back. I've waited on the crowded patio for the only server to take my order. I've stood at an empty bar waiting for one of the bartenders to take my drink order.   But last night took the cake as I had a bartender sneer at me as I ordered and had him throw my card back at me after I'd asked to open a tab. Like, huh? And my reward? A mediocre, watered down cocktail.  That'll be my last trip to The Abbey until they get the front of the house in order (and give that bartender a lesson in, you know, bartending). The drinks are too expensive and too meh to deal with the poor service when there are so many other options available. Honestly, if it weren't for the patio I wouldn't have given them a second, and third, and fourth, etc., try.

u2ykgeSusvkq1RHMsW6naw.text: Nobody should ever have stress associated with going out for dinner/drinks. Some cust bartendress in back was unwarrantedly rude and petty, which was unfortunate.   Otherwise, nice interior. Cool design and concept. The coffee bar guy is always friendly. The front bar gets packed when many people cram into it. But understandable given the cool vibe of the place.   The initial visit I had was good. But this most recent interaction brought down my thoughts on the place some.

e52ixOQGGyh3U6oyEQm25w.text: We had an incredible lunch here today. The attentive staff seated is quickly. Our waiter (the awesome Shawn!) was there within seconds  with water and menus. Eveything came on time and fresh. Great time, great food and impeccable service. I had the special of grilled mahi mahi with a giant scallop over tomato risotto dome perfectly with the rose' which paired nicely. Raving all day. Will return many times!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Get this today!
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Perfect texture! Hard to do with mahi mahi, scallops and a smoked tomato risotto! Bravo babes!
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Our helpful, charming, witty waiter Shawn!

AL717x2MNijFstFzk95DZw.text: This "restaurant" is more like 4 great businesses in one! There is 1) the huge bar room with TVs and great tap list, then 2) the coffee shop with comfy couches and a badass fireplace, then 3) there is the huge outdoor patio with fountain and another badass fireplace, and then 4) last, but certainly not least, there is the dining room with tables and booths and another full bar.   Each of the four venues is intimately sequestered from the other, so you can be completely absorbed in the atmosphere of where you are (i.e. when you are in the coffee shop, you don't feel like your at a bar). The result, however, is a little confusing when you first arrive because most people are used to restaurants being one thing and one thing only. With the Abbey, it feels like a maze of entertainment that changes around every corner. However, once you get the tour, it's easier to wrap your mind around than you think.   I have never been too impressed with the food or drinks. I love a good cocktail and mine was so sour that I couldn't finish it. Seems like an issue with the bartender more than the menu. Hopefully, once they get their groove going, we see an improvement in the food and drinks. I am optimistic they will figure it out.

CWrOk6fDBI_T-fuVMe3_UQ.text: we're always looking for someplace new. we tried to go once before, but we were told it was between lunch & dinner, & no food was being made! so this was our 2nd attempt. the place is pretty big with lots of different rooms. tom said it used to be a funeral home. it was dark with lots of heavy looking wood. it wasn't until i saw the menu that i realized it was supposed to be an English themed restaurant. on the way out, i noticed words from a queen song written on the wall. okaaaaay..... the menu isn't big, but they have a little of everything. we ordered the arancini balls. they were nicely fried on the outside & very soft on the inside. the rice was mixed with chopped jalapenos, & had some cheese in the center. they were wonderful! crunchy, soft, & a little sass!  we both got the seared tuna with watermelon radishes, & grilled green beans with onion. the tuna was perfectly done. the radishes had a little vinaigrette on them, & played well with the tuna. the grilled beans were excellent as well. we just wished there was more! dessert was a chocolate toffee torte that was outstanding for me, & a chocolate chip cheesecake for tom.  what we had was great, but there wasn't a big selection of anything, including the wine. what we got was most likely the only thing we would order. the staff was nice enough, though they seemed aloof.  would we go back? eh.

gnqgXirFByCO0Hx5gkT26g.text: I've come here a few times at this point. The coffee is great, and the male barista (baristo?) seems to have it under control every time I see him, even at 9am singlehandedly making drinks for a line of customers.  That being said, my experience with the bar was less impressive. I ordered a cocktail, which was tasty, but I felt literally nothing after drinking it... If I'm going to pay $9 for a cocktail, I expect it to contain enough alcohol to at least have some effect.  I'll be going back often for coffee, but it's unlikely I'll bother with the bar again.

QRZA71F09w3i9G8FSz2jSw.text: Great place and great food! Dined with a group of workers for lunch. Nice place for groups. Large selection of craft beers and the food was memorable. All of us enjoyed the same entree: chicken gouda sandwich with fries, slaw or vegetable side. It recommended by the waitress and it was a great choice. The sandwich was flavorful and had a delicious spread on it. The coffee bar was a surprise. We split a cookie among the six of us. It was by far one of the best chocolate chip cookies that I have eaten. Beautiful mysterious decor which I later understood the mysterious because it used to be a funeral parlor. The space is full of decorative surprises including an old organ, door with a wine cork handle, large wooden doors and a patio that makes you feel at home. Nice fountain and brick columns. It's perfect on a nice day.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken Gouda sandwich with garlic aioli and fries.
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Entrance
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Old organ

NDchP0tTr3pF2iTCB5nvDg.text: I only went for coffee, and it was a great place to settle down with a Scrabble game to relax. I got the affogato, which was really yummy. They use vanilla ice cream and a little whipped cream. I'm not usually a fan of whipped cream, but there was only a little bit of whipped cream, so the overall mix was great. They use Commonhouse Coffee (located in Squirrel Hill) for their espresso base, so I knew what to expect.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Behind the coffee bar
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Forgot to take a picture of the environment before I already had some of the affogato. Definitely good and cute.
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Affogato -- definitely worth the money

Ypt4q4WcWYpFErQI5f_bSA.text: First, the good- The servers and staff are helpful and friendly. The space itself is large so I can't imagine seating will ever be an issue and there is a big outdoor space (huge bonus). Now, the bad- Went here for brunch. The only option currently is an $18 brunch buffet that includes an alcoholic beverage. The buffet included your typical french toast, eggs, bacon, steak, pastries, etc. It reminded me of bad cruise food. I was completely underwhelmed. I am not sure how their brunch is going to survive with so many other delicious options nearby.   I might come back here for a beverage but  I will not be coming here to eat again.

I0eOC0HBgi8TFcOz4cO_ug.text: If you're a hip millennial who wants to pay for some overpriced eggs, this is your brunch spot. I've heard great things about their brunch, so finally, I got a chance to try it out. The restaurant has a classy casual vibe with a nice big bar area. We opted to sit in the outdoor patio area since it was a nice day. Their brunch menu has all the brunch essentials, but as a vegetarian, the only options I had (and liked) were the vegetable omelette and the biscuits & gravy (the gravy is made from veggie sausage). I went for the vegetable omelette which comes with their breakfast potatoes. Unfortunately they don't offer egg whites which was disappointing. The food was definitely not seasoned enough (or at all). It was decent for an eggs and potatoes dish but nothing wow'd me.   There is a small private lot to the right of the restaurant which I'm sure fills up very quickly. This is one of the few places in Lawrenceville that actually have a parking lot.   Overall, it was a 3 star experience. The atmosphere is great for a Sunday brunch date, but the food isn't anything I'd write home about.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable Omelet Brunch

gkG0S6YICfIkUNL4ghSBNQ.text: I struggle with somewhere between a 3.5 and a 4 but definitely not a 3 or a 5. Went for brunch one Sunday had a decent meal. I ordered the lamb burger, my brother got the chicken and waffles which he loved and my mom had the regular breakfast meal with eggs and pancakes and kielbasa. My lamb burger was good. My moms pancakes weren't cooked like completely raw but they immediately brought out new ones and I will say the new ones were very very good. Like really good pancakes. I struggle with the prices though. My lamb burger was $16 I think and a side salad Instead of the pasta salad was an extra 3 dollars. I also ordered a side of 2 biscuits that cost $6. $23 brunch for a normal amount of food is pretty crazy.   Stopped at the cafe on the way out for a coffee to go and they were super confused and making wrong coffees and my latte was pretty average

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lamb burger
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken and waffle

7PBXXzp29Qkvjh6nLE7YFw.text: I came here to work and sip on coffee. It's got a good set up for that, or to come and eat with some friends. They have a bar, and an outdoor patio, too.  OH and to combat the plastic straw thing, they have straws made from hay? Not as weird as it sounds I promise.

b0qRWp1YZ288BgYtKW-_Fw.text: Great food and atmosphere!  Delicious steak and fries! Great happy hour!   All happy faces here- we had fried ravioli, hummus plate, scallop linguine, buff Mac and cheese, and veggie burger!

cCH3EIr-4GALOMzFUY7xAA.text: Been here quite a few times now and everyone time has been great! The atmosphere is totally cool you forget your in a old funeral home. Love the lyrics to Bohemian Rhapsody on the wall.   Been to their drag queen bingo it was so much fun I hope they do it again.   Brunch is awesome. They have a Bloody Mary bar.   Last visit my eggs Benedict were over cooked I didn't want to make big deal out of it and my server noticed and brought me out new ones .   I will and do come here often!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried Green Tomatoes
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Smoked Salmon Eggs Benedict

yCsRCCTvJ8GgIkO6lh9Rkw.text: Okay, hands up! Who doesn't want to visit a converted Funeral Home turned into a restaurant? Yeah... doesn't sound that appealing does it?! Well, if nothing else, it makes for a good story to tell your friends. We are always up for something interesting and new so we decided to make our way to The Abbey on Butler Street.   We got there very early on a Sunday for dinner after the brunch crowd had left so the entire time we were eating we were the only ones in the dining room. The servers were still getting all the silverware and everything ready for dinner service rush.  The two of us decided on the lamb shank and the steak frites entrees. My shank was very meaty and so tender it fell right off the bone. The spaetzle was a nice addition, you don't see that on very many menus. My husband's steak frites was just basic, nothing interesting or spectacular to note of that dish.  Probably one of the highlights of the evening was the dessert, the malva cake. It looked like a very generic type of cake but had a wonderful flavor. It had been brushed with a delicious apricot glaze, and the crunch of the crystalized sugar added just the perfect texture to the cake. Served with a dollop of whipped cream on the side. A light, but filling ending to our meal.   No military discount offered here.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steak Frites
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Malva Cake
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lamb Shank

iYypuWc7wLUIHO19BmzeNA.text: Good drinks, good vibes, good service.  * Drinks: I didn't end up eating here but got drinks instead. I ordered their Rosemary Fizz and I really enjoyed it. It wasn't too sweet and wasn't too strong either. They had a lot of drink options that sounded really good and I wish I ordered another one.   * Price vs. Worth: Most of their mixed drinks was $10 which is the average price in Pittsburgh.   Will I come here again? - Yes and I will probably try their food next time. I noticed they had beautiful outside seating as well which was gated and had a small fountain.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Rosemary Fizz

dUxIF19d0gqEsiQ4gE47Bw.text: I've been to the Abbey a couple times.  Each time - it's been nothing to write home about.  I've only gone for brunch - so maybe I need to try it for dinner.  I love trying different places versions of eggs benedict.  Honestly - because of my love of poached eggs.   While it wasn't called anything near an eggs benedict - because honestly - it wasn't.  I wanted to try to the Welsh Rarebit with a side of bacon.    The Welsh Rarebit looked unique - and scrumptious.  Especially with that poached egg.  Well....it was more like a hard boiled egg.  While it was done in the form of a poached egg - that egg yolk had no run to it.  It was hard.  I was so disappointed.  I said something to the waiter and he told me that was what poached eggs were supposed to be.  (Please feel free to correct me if I'm wrong - but they are supposed to have a bit of yolk run...right?! - or have i been eating poached eggs wrong everywhere else?)  I did ask for a side of bacon.  I was grateful that it wasn't "soggy" bacon.  But burnt bacon was not what I was anticipating.  It was dark, burnt bacon.  Not just well done - it was WELL done to burnt.  Overall I was disappointed.  I may be willing to try the Abbey for dinner sometime - but I've certainly given it enough chances on brunch.

C7RYqGCKxxKeAeVvZqyfOw.text: Put half a dozen church women in the Abbey on a sunny weekday, and you'll get a chatty table full of salads, burgers, and hash, and well lubricated by the summer sangria (tastes like juice). The humus and pita appetizer was big enough for the whole table. My Makers Bourbon peanut butter and bacon burger tasted like it had sat for a while--the cheese could have been more melted--but it was otherwise unobjectionable. The more I ate into it, the more I tasted the bourbon in the peanut butter smeared on the bottom. The consensus was that the current pasta side salad is better than the old one, before the menu was changed. Come early or call to make a reservation if you want to eat outside in the courtyard under a bright red umbrella with the sound of the splashing fountain.  Minus one star for waiting 15 minutes to pay, after the server finally brought our checks.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Makers Bourbon PB burger

XnkFwlWJCgJkvMql7A0z2w.text: Had the pleasure of trying TABS while in town for work.  The staff and atmosphere were fantastic and the menu had the type of creativity and flavor that chain dining could never compete with!  The food style could be described as comfort food with a modern twist.  Great cocktail and wine list too.  Cheers!

iN9d4X3hLAtwLYvJ6qWZ_A.text: Been here a few times and it has been a really enjoyable experience each visit!  I have met friends here on a few occasions to grab drinks and catch up. We have sat both inside and out, and I can say both are great options. In the summer, sitting outside was nice if you aren't in the direct sunlight. The patio has nice seating but it can be hard to be comfortable and still hear the person across from you. The sofas are oddly deep. The indoor bar seating is also great too and you can order food service here as well. Evenings tend to fill quickly so I suggest arriving a bit earlier than the late crowd to get optimal tables.  The drink service has always been great. Wide variety of beers on tap to select from along with a unique cocktail menu. I stuck with beers on my visits but friends raved about the cocktails. Worth stopping by if you are looking for a laid back place in Lawrenceville!

jey8okWSqwoQcCVQWmDB_Q.text: Terri was such an amazing barista. She cared about what we wanted and had heart in the whole process. As someone who works in the industry, it is really refreshing to encounter someone who is so willing to take care of their customers. Have more people like her!

0qokJ7LecBt4968bR8JssQ.text: What a fun place with a cool laid back atmosphere! We had a table for 11 in the corner which was great for our large brunch group. The service was good and the server was friendly. We enjoyed that we were by the window and felt the warmth of the sun on this rare sunny day this winter winter. I loved the pancake breakfast special I got and the French 75 cocktail. I definitely would recommend this cozy spot for brunch with friends.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pancake breakfast combo
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brunch cocktails
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable omelet

otAHbMBLNa09ooRt8B5IYQ.text: I was really pleased with the two nearby parking lots that are designated for patrons of The Abbey. This made parking an ease. As I walked into the place, a door handle filled with coffee beans greeted me which was a pleasant surprise!! The atmosphere inside is very warm, with a semi Art Deco feel. I only ordered the edamame hummus here. But boy-was it good! I'm a huge garlic fanatic, so I really appreciate the fresh garlic taste I get from the hummus. The service was really quick too! I came in at around 1:15PM on a Saturday. I placed my order, and it came out within five minutes.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

EKNqUwqJEGHZh9whBTfm5A.text: I guess a hip vibe if you are here for atmosphere, coffee or drinks but to me the food is hit or miss and pricey. I may give it another shot -- the staff was somewhat attentive. I found it odd that the waiter never actually passed out our menus he just sat a pile of them on the table and then another staff came to take our orders and I said well I never got a menu and she said that they were on the table so I kind of felt dumb in asking -- this is the third time I have been here since it opened and I don't plan on returning unless my friends suggest going -- to me there are better choices in the area.

1thBHqNYb-jJJw505E1bAw.text: This fine restaurant has been on my list for a while and so glad today I was able to experience everything it had to offer.  We went after brunch was over for an early dinner.   I had researched the history of the restaurant and the decor inside so so cool and refreshing- unlike any other place in the area.  Used to be a funeral home. Spacious and welcoming at the same time.   I chose the lamb burger and fries - which was very good.   Members of my party ordered the fish and chips and could not stop raving about them.  We had the option of sitting inside or out.  We chose inside and loved it! The service was great and can't beat parking on the street right in front of the restaurant!!   I love Lawrenceville but sometimes parking can be an issue.. since The Abbey is down a bit from the cluster of restaurants.. parking is no doubt hassle free.   We cannot wait to visit again!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. lamb burger
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

jSlxACeZwiDvYSMxHkkMPA.text: Went here with a friend for lunch. We didn't order much, just a few apps, but they were amazing. We got their curry fries and edamame hummus. Both were unique and tasty. I will dream about the curry fries. I would love to go back and try more menu items.  We say outside on the patio with was really nice.  As for service, we did have to chase down or waitress so we could pay, which was frustrating.  So food was 5 stars, service 3.

X1j-kRGIoWN5zoP4RPgOtA.text: We were able to sit outside near the fountain on a nice summer night. The food and service were great. The only issue we had was with the steak salad. The steak was a bit tough and stringy. However, the burger was probably one of the best we've ever had. The fish dishes were also fabulous. We will certainly return!

juBQqnQT1QDYVJEDHlTuTg.text: Stopped here for lunch. The service was fast and friendly. The place has a cool ex-funeral home vibe, which is kinda cool.  The lighting and seating are hipster and cool.  I ordered a southern fried chicken sandwich. It was really good. For starters it was made with dark meat. That alone makes it worth trying.  It was like a high end niche version of a chick-fil-a original sandwich. I would definitely return.

wwIAPws4juW6o2RAuGqHrQ.text: Bar Side: lots of tables and space for small/medium groups. We have celebrated birthdays here, met up with friends, and had date nights which all seemed to be suited by The Abbey! It's got a very cool looking exterior of an older fancy building but the inside has a very woodsy and polished look. Beer selection is great - they've also got TVs by the bar for those who want to watch games!   Coffee shop: So cozy and comforting! I love meeting up with friends here for chatting or a pre-going out coffee. My only (small) quip is that  most times here, I received my coffee in a to go cup when I've been asked and specified a coffee for here. Very much not a big deal, but just something I noticed after a few times. They serve great coffee and espresso, but also offer some alcoholic dessert coffee drinks that look great! They also have a lot of snacks and pastries to enjoy while there. A great overall experience for the most part!
