HXMg5esObrtPOePWICbI9w.text: 11 our of 10 Stars!  Food, atmosphere and service was outstanding and the price point can't be beat!

URf6j__HQDAl5ee8LO3p6g.text: So having once lived in the city, then moving north about 40 miles .... One learns to cherish their city moments when they get them.  This past Sunday at The Abbey was one of those times, and the Abby did not disappoint in the slightest.  My wife and I met friends for brunch.  Our first choice was packed so our friends suggested The Abbey.  Their brunch buffet is remarkable, and the Bloody Mary bar is equally as impressive.  It was perfect.  Exactly what we needed.  I'm pretty confident the next time the call for brunch arises ... The Abbey will be first on our list for a re-visit.  Highly recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

qFv1tMw9sSemqT4d4MGVvw.text: Normally I would have nothing but good things to say about The Abbey but my experience tonight was infuriating. My wife and I had dinner at another establishment and decided to have drinks at The Abbey afterward, which we did. No sooner did we leave, my brother called to tell me he was at The Abbey, so we turned around to go back. We bought drinks inside, and went out to the patio and sat at the empty table beside my brother. A few minutes later the hostess came over and asked if we were eating- we said no, and she told us that the patio tables were reserved for customers who were eating, and if they got busy we would have to leave. Fine. The patio was mainly empty with a few parties trickling in. Not 10 minutes later she came back to tell us they needed the table and we had to leave. THERE WERE 11 EMPTY TABLES ON THE PATIO. I called and spoke to Mark the manager to tell him of my ridiculous experience and he merely reiterated what the hostess said, offering nothing to try to keep an irate customer from never coming back. By the way, I called my brother about 20 minutes later and he told me no one was ever seated at the table I was forced to leave. If I could give Mark and his hostess 0 stars I would. Ridiculous. There are plenty of places in Pittsburgh to have a relaxing drink.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Ee8cvsRKvjGm5hro62lUlw.text: I've gone to the Abbey a few times and I have to say that it is slightly disjointed. There is a coffee bar in the middle of the restaurant and it seems like an odd decision to make when there could be more tables added. We waited a good bit for a table and so this is probably me just being a spoiled diva, but I wouldn't have had to wait so long if there were tables in the center area. We had friends that had a table by the bar and they gave it to us when they left. The bartender came over to clear it off and was pretty rude about it. Luckily she was not our server and the server was very nice. I ordered the shepherd's pie and it was really good but really salty. I love overly salty things so I was fine with it. However, I can easily see someone being overpowered with the sodium levels. I also have to say...the fries on top? Quit it. There were way too many fries and not enough stew. I enjoyed the dish but there were definitely some areas that could be improved. I'm in no rush to come back anytime soon.

ILNwX8QMfoHOYb4IVyINaQ.text: I really want to like The Abbey, and the truth is, I *do* like it. But I feel like it's in that in-between stage where it's trying to figure out how to be everything to everybody, and hasn't *quite* hit the target yet, and I have to be very specific about the timing of when I want to visit, and for what.  The Abbey is part coffeeshop, part bar, and part restaurant. It's in the space of a former funeral home, which this death positive girl really loves. There's a lovely outdoor patio with a fountain, for when the weather is nice. And the hallway is lined with lyrics to Queen's "Bohemian Rhapsody."   The coffeeshop area is very cute. During the day, it's a perfect coffeeshop atmosphere. But because there's very little in terms of walls between the coffeeshop section and the bar, as soon as the bar begins to get loud, the sound makes its way over to the coffeeshop area as well.  We've been in a number of times, several times with large groups. The bar service has always been awesome. They've done their best to accommodate the large groups, and if you're just a solo girl with a book who wants to read and sip wine, they are more than accommodating for that, too.  It's mostly the menu where I think things fall flat for me. The options seem a little all-over-the-place and kind of disjointed. On one visit, we had pork belly bruschetta. Sounds interesting, but it just was not meant to be, flavor-profile-wise. And the fried zucchini was just waaaaay too heavy to have as an appetizer. That's filling enough for your lunch, your dinner, and maybe part of breakfast the next morning.  One menu item that is not to miss, however, is the edamame hummus. It is just incredible. Flavorful, savory, and served with warm, soft naan bread.  In terms of booze: if you're a beer drinker, it seems they've really got you covered. I am not, but they have a good selection of wine, and although their tequila section is small, it's more than adequate. They also have a sizable cocktail menu that rotates seasonally.  I think The Abbey is still working out some of the kinks of being a triple-feature event. For example, when we went in for a sit-down dinner one night, we wanted dessert, but we had to cash out at the restaurant and leave our table, then order a pastry from the coffeeshop area. It was like having dinner and then going to a different space for dessert, and I wasn't really into that.  But, if you're gathering for a few drinks and some hummus, this is a good spot. It's a solid 3.5 stars, a place I will definitely return to, and a locale that I will absolutely update my review on as time goes by and they start to nail the concept.

l46yJS-tOQUCtLIrwJuiKw.text: Stopped off for appetizers and a couple drinks and really enjoyed the place.  Siracha chicken dip was amazing and the mac n cheese was tasty.  Beer selection was great and even had some Arsenal Cider. Definitely worth stopping in.

s2FsujhuUTqgKvJUMvsNKA.text: My wife and I stopped here for dinner, because we saw that they were featuring the new Oscar blues IPA  on tap. We wanted to also eat here because they have great outdoor seating.  We ordered the fish and chips and Shepard's pie. Both were delicious and pretty generous portions. I thought it was reasonably priced and well worth the money. We will definitely stop here again. This place also has a coffee house inside which smelled really good when walking through to get to the back patio. I may have to stop and try that one day as well. Another one of many great resturaunts in Lawrenceville.

SCQMISEgFMIhH9HY7Ts4zg.text: Wow they have some great apps! My son mean mugged the staff the whole time and they were great sports about it. It was a nice dinner with my girlfriends and we had a good time. They even had some jazz music live when we were leaving.

5QcydSuoZOeOGvHImLBmbQ.text: My family stopped in here without a reservation.  The hostess told us there weren't any tables available even though half of the place was empty.  She then proceeded to just stare at us blankly.  When I asked if we could sit in the bar area she became reanimated and said yes, that would be ok.  Why she didn't offer that herself is beyond me.  In any case, the bartender was friendly and attentive, the food was good and the atmosphere is great.  Very hip crowd.  We had bangers and mash and mussels.  They weren't the best I've had but were above average.  I would go here again just make sure you have a reservation so the pretty hostess doesn't have to think for herself.

n3ktCL5kPqsyYd9Hc65yvg.text: beautiful evening sitting out on patio. service was very good...drinks wonderful! food was fresh...was bummed out lamb burgers sold out by 5...our server was very accommodating. nice crowd on patio

DjIW35Sqkwa3kNAMSqxvsQ.text: Did I just eat brunch at The Abbey or at the Hilton Garden Inn? For a whopping $18 you are offered a buffet that includes gummy scrambled eggs, over seasoned potato wedges, greasy thin strips of bacon, sausage, old French toast, hockey puck biscuits, vegan gravy, and a made to order omelettes station (the only positive).  Their selection of brunch cocktails cost eight dollars each. Get ready to spend a lot of money for a very lackluster brunch.

SPa7R0Na0hN5yFqYIAUTaw.text: Stopped in the coffee house yesterday and enjoyed sitting on the veranda in the nice weather. The selection was huge and we enjoyed every sip. The little tables on the veranda are, well, little. A tad bigger would be better as two of us had to hold our coffee and pastry on our knee. Have been there before for coffee and for also for drinks at the bar and enjoyed ourselves.   It was interesting to see that there were two woman parked on the two large sofas. One had two sofas taken up with her laptop, purse, etc. another lady was sitting with her feet up.  Saw us looking for a place to sit but made no offer to move their stuff. We were fortunate that a patron invited us to sit in his little area.   We will be back though. Parking is a plus.

WDL9FKJ0Zoa7Yd9F4fDv5w.text: It's really a shame. They have all the makings of a decent, even incredible spot. The Abbey made a major misstep and opted to invest all of their tremendous budget on the renovation and clearly not into a menu.  The deep fried zucchini is like what teenager would make if gave them a deep fryer.  Their servers do not know what their bar or cafe has to offer, waiters seem to forget tables while the manger smoozes the tables with scripted questions rotating uncomfortably between tables. I didn't offer my honest opinion with my first brunch visit here. (I've had better complementary motel brunches.) I was shocked the brunch it served in hot plates and there is no menu just help yourself.  I hope they get it together.    The stars this place gets is for its top notch bar tenders and barista who should be running the show. The food is subpar and I've given this place three shotsLots of potential, not clear vision.   Good coffee, good bar. Food is a fail. Service is lacking.

PdYU8LwpO14dIO6xFxQERw.text: This restaurant is a gem! It is very interesting inside and the food and drinks were excellent. Definitely returning in the future.

pgCP_QeLVObiJp8ArrO60Q.text: I've been here several times and this place is phenomenal! Drinks, coffee or food - all good choices! Great place to meet friends, eat a delicious meal quietly, or hang out and get some work done in the coffee house section. Staff is super friendly and accommodating and makes you feel like they're glad you're here. highly recommend this place!  (Just had the corn cakes and crab and it was awesome!)

SETJXLce4AOjrb-PZNqz5w.text: I'm not sure I would ever go back here.   We had a table for 10 outside starting at around 9pm for a friends very lowkey birthday. Around 10pm 2 more friends showed up and we asked for 2 more chairs to fit around the table which had plenty of room. The manager Bob or Rob, came up to us and said he would not be giving us any more chairs and our friends were not welcome to stand around the table ether. At this point it was 10pm and 3 2top tables were next to us so our 2 friends sat down at one of those within 10min Bob was back and asked me if the gentleman and lady at that table were with us(instead of asking them directly), and that he needed that table back because he was on a wait. We begrudgingly gave the table back because we had a feeling he was not on a wait and lone behold he was lying not 1 person sat down at those tables the rest of the night.    Moral of this story is I understand Bob did not want us having 2 more people join our party but the way he went about it was just completely unnecessary. This is clearly a restaurant that was renovated by someone with money but no real restaurant experience. No one in FOH seemed to know what the hell they were doing and were some of the most unaccommodating people I have ever met. I tried this restaurant its first week and it was awful(the food and the service) and this just sealed for me I will never go back, I would rather spend my money at Wendy's down the street than The Abbey.

xQv5SDa-WVfq4ayV5g_JwQ.text: Busy but well staffed. Very eclectic motif. The windows/ decor are gorgeous.  Great beers on tap and tasty menus for food. Outdoor dining.. patio too.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

HHCbI4-Qh63LcxgXSGwZiA.text: The Abbey has a really cool vibe, which I was immediately drawn to. The inside of the restaurant is dark with a lot of seating area. I particularly enjoyed the courtyard on the restaurant side (I also learned there is a courtyard on the bar side!). It was a beautiful summer evening to sit outside and the courtyard and fountain outside made for a lovely atmosphere.  Unfortunately, I was unimpressed with the food. The menu was solid, with a lot of really neat cocktail options and a variety of food options for your dining needs. I went with a sandwich because I wasn't very hungry and it seemed like an easy and safe choice. It was completely adequate, but nothing I would return for. I will definitely be back to The Abbey in the future, but probably only for the cool coffee cocktails.

Ls5FyN6B-MUVigqCoAefmw.text: I want to preface this review with the fact that I was going to rate 3 stars, but upon clicking 3 stars Yelp prompted "A-OK" and 2 stars prompted "Meh. I've experienced better" and after reading the text, I align most with the meh. So, consider it somewhere between a 2 and a 3.  Let's start with atmosphere... the place itself is really cool. It's super dark inside but that's the vibe they are going for so I'm cool with it. The place is separated into a couple different areas/rooms which all seemed really similar-themed from my walkthrough. We had a reservation for 6 and had hoped to sit outside, but were told when we arrived that the patio was full. I was definitely a little annoyed since we made a reservation ahead of time and added in the comments the preference for outside, but oh well.  In terms of service... wow. I'm not sure where to begin. Honestly, the service was completely awful. Our waiter was polite but we saw him 3 times over the course of our 2 hour meal. We went most of the time with no water or drink refills which was displeasing. We had hoped to stay a bit and order more drinks and talk, but we weren't even given the opportunity. I didn't even get to order a first cocktail because our waiter left once and never came back.  The food was pretty average. I got a chicken sandwich and it was mostly bread. The chicken itself was pretty dry... ALSO of note: the menu says that the side included is pasta salad. IT IS NOT PASTA SALAD. The side dish is macaroni salad made with different noodles than macaroni. I'm not a fan of mayo so I figured the pasta salad would be delicious, but I was extremely disappointed to find macaroni salad on my plate. Wanted to share for those who also do not want mayo-covered pasta as your side dish. As far as food goes, the only thing I would recommend was the edamame hummus which was better than the rest of the food combined.   Overall, I would give it: Atmosphere: 4 stars (I liked it) Food: 2 stars (Meh; except for the hummus which was good) Service: 1 star (Non-existent)

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken sandwich (dry, hardly any avocado) and &#34;pasta salad&#34; which is actually macaroni salad

gPSMH6HMqEmWngaqiYkQUA.text: I've been to the Abbey twice and have had wonderful experiences both times! The food and drinks menu have unique, delicious selections. I always get the Edamame hummus for an appetizer. Don't be weirded out by the color (light green)! It is SO delicious and I love the Naan with it! You can get half naan and half vegetables too if you want. They definitely have healthier options too if you're looking for that.   I ordered the Samurai's Edge which literally tasted like a delicious matcha latte! This was from their tea cocktails. They also have coffee cocktails which are so yummy!   This place isn't just a night-time outing; they are also open in the day for coffee! I love the decor inside! There are board games and places to lounge both inside and outside! Can't wait to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Samurais Edge tea cocktail
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Edamame Hummus Dinner

53Jd6Et3bwSbyNyJ3-58AQ.text: Cool atmosphere! There's a large tea list. The bar list is tempting. The one barista behind the bar is quick. That's about it for the positive part of the review.   I almost never give reviews under 4 stars, and have been working my way through the coffee shops around the city for the past few months, so keep this in mind for the rest of the review.   They have three drip coffees ready for the morning crowd: a light, medium, and bold brew. I asked about the flavor profiles of the coffees since the board went so far as listing the countries of origin for the beans. I've had enough experience ordering bold coffees that are just burnt tasting, so I wanted to make sure I wasn't ordering barbecued beans. I ended up ordering the medium roast and my friend got the bold. Neither cups were good. I managed to salvage mine with cream and sugar. Even then, the half and half tasted like it had been out for days. My friend's bold coffee tasted burnt without anything added, so I suggested following suit with cream and sugar. I took a sip after the additions, and it tasted like watered down sour milk. He didn't drink the rest of it. I also ordered the cinnamon mango muffin. It was dry but fine.

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cinnamon mango muffin and medium roast coffee

NPd7Rrod1fXcjLcxzrHicQ.text: Tons of beer options, amazing food. Probably the best restaurant in this price range I've ever been to.  You can sit at the bar or a table inside. There's separate restaurant seating inside and outside. I sat outside this time and there's lots of patio furniture and nice seating, there's even a nice water fountain in the middle!  They have the best fish and chips I have ever tried here. Fresh-tasting Alaskan cod with a crispy, tasty batter. It comes with seasoned fries which were fried perfectly, lightly crunchy on the outside and super soft on the inside.  I had the Abbey burger, and it was also one of the best burgers I've ever had. Perfectly cooked, juicy without being too greasy. Comes with thick cut bacon that wasn't soft, but not too crispy either. It comes with pasta salad, which was also really good.  The only item that I have any complaints with were the wings. They were pretty over salted. Still edible, but way too much salt. They had a great flavor to them and I'm sure if they were less salty they'd also be the best wings I've ever had. They were perfectly cooked and juicy. They came garnished with blue cheese on top and ranch dressing on the side.

w3zqhHfk2j1wo1qa3w-IKg.text: I've heard mixed reviews about The Abbey on Butler Street, so I wanted to go check it out myself. I heard that they only had pretzel sticks on their menu, but they had recently changed their menu so I was pleasantly surprised.   We went on Wednesday night around 6pm. There was a party happening in the front bar, but we got seated in the back bar/dining room area. To be honest, it was pretty dark. I liked the vibe, but I wouldn't say it's very kid friendly. Seems like it would a good location for a date night or catching up with friends.  To start, we ordered the pretzel bread and it was delicious. My dad ordered the fish and chips and my mom ordered a burger, and I ordered plain Mac & cheese. Overall, the food was good. I might order something differently next time.   In the end, I would definitely go back and would want to try something new.

YtahYdH0Dz8THj3KHL8N0A.text: I went to the Abbey for the first time and was not disappointed.  I met a couple of friends there and we had some drinks and lunch.  I had a bloody mary to start and ordered that spicy and it was fantastic.  I then followed that up with the Butler Street Mule and that was extraordinary.  I  ordered a Caprese sandwich and that was good.  I did not eat it all because it was a large portion but very good.  I ordered a 3rd cocktail, the lavender in fashion and this one finally did me in.  I had the punch I was I was looking for but that could have been the other two drinks ganging up on me as well.  So, after all, was said and done the service was awesome, food was superb, and the drinks were out of this word.  The patio seating was great too.  Come here for everything and leave full and happy.

cgnZgBAC7U7PrahHBrU8mQ.text: This place has grown in me for sure. When they first started it went through some new opening weirdness that threw me. But I have steadily came back for more. Throughout the years they have gotten into a pretty seamless rhythm and I can honestly say I come here more frequently because of that. Even to the point of suggesting it as a go to place for family and friends visiting the area.  They have and outside area, coffee shop, restaurant seating, and two bar areas. Honestly, there is a space and a place for everyone. You pick where you want to be and just relax.  Their menu has also steadily has gotten better over time. I was here recently for brunch and their Nashville Hot Chicken was no joke. Thigh meat between a cornbread (I believe) waffle. Can you ask for anything better? It was delish.  I have even brought my younger nephews here and they found things to like on the menu and they are picky kids.   Come here, the employees are great and so is the food.

J4O8dy56B2FGmuqQ7m5fuQ.text: Great food and atmosphere! Been here a couple of times and I think I always have the veggie burger but everyone's meals looked great and were well enjoyed! Will be back again for sure. Price is reasonable too.

yc822W7O1lhUlM4MjkI4Jw.text: All I can say is WOW! We've heard great things about the Sunday brunch here but we never imagined it would be this amazing. Creative coffee cocktails make this cozy restaurant stand out from the crowd. As soon as you touch the first step, you're introduced to the staple of the Abbey, coffee beans. I mean the door handle is literally full of coffee beans!   The service was awesome, as we were seated promptly at a comfortable table with plenty of natural lighting. It's almost as if you can taste each individual ingredient used in every dish and drink. I highly recommend the cheddar bacon biscuits, veggie omelette or the pancake breakfast. The biscuits were so soft, they practically melt in your mouth. The omelette tasted as if the vegetables were hand picked from a garden right outside, I couldn't have asked for more.  I could probably go on and on forever about how perfect our experience was, but I feel like I still wouldn't be doing The Abbey any justice. Stop by for brunch or just stop by for a coffee and prepare to be stunned!

photos.caption: Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of The Abbey on Butler Street - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

M9XjKAmHP0UUS0NdBhQzGQ.text: As soon I stepped into The Abbey I felt like I was transported back in time to the rustic golden age of Pittsburgh. The ceilings, chandeliers, fireplace, and overall feel just screamed good vibes.   The food was good. I had the Shrimp & Grits which were sweet & salty just like you want them. My dining partner in crime had the Nashville Hot which was bursting with flavor from the bacon fat oil that it's made in.   The real 5 star rating came from the service. Our waiter for Sunday Brunch gave me some of the best service I've had while dining out ever. Great experience from walking in to walking out. Nice, attentive, funny, great with suggestions, cool, and some other reasons I can't remember. I'm not sure how they recruit or how them employees are trained but other restaurants can learn from The Abbey.
